etymologies: late Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘burn as the sun does, parch’): from Old French toster ‘roast’, from Latin torrere ‘parch’. The practice of drinking a toast (toast (sense 2 of the noun)) goes back to the late 17th century, and originated in naming a lady whose health the company was requested to drink, the idea being that the lady's name flavored the drink like the pieces of spiced toast that were formerly placed in drinks such as wine

definitions: sliced bread browned on both sides by exposure to radiant heat

examples.text: she buttered a slice of toast

shortDefinitions: sliced bread browned on both sides by exposure to radiant heat

definitions: a call to a gathering of people to raise their glasses and drink together in honor of a person or thing, or an instance of drinking in this way

examples.text: he raised his glass in a toast to his son

shortDefinitions: call to gathering of people to raise their glasses and drink together in honour of person or thing

definitions: a person or thing that is very popular or held in high regard by a particular group of people

examples.text: he found himself the toast of the baseball world

shortDefinitions: person or thing that is very popular or held in high regard by particular group of people

definitions: cook or brown (food, especially bread or cheese) by exposure to a grill, fire, or other source of radiant heat

examples.text: he sat by the fire and toasted a piece of bread

definitions: (of food) cook or become brown by exposure to radiant heat

examples.text: broil until the nuts have toasted

shortDefinitions: cook or become brown by exposure to radiant heat

definitions: warm (oneself or part of one's body) in front of a fire or other source or heat

examples.text: Tim was toasting his feet by the fire
we were spread out on the grass toasting ourselves one hot day

shortDefinitions: warm in front of fire or other source or heat

definitions: drink to the health or in honor of (someone or something) by raising one's glass together with others

examples.text: happy families toasting each other's health
he is toasted by the trade as the outstanding dealer in children's books

shortDefinitions: drink to health or in honour of person or thing

etymologies: 1970s: perhaps the same word as toast

definitions: (of a DJ) accompany a reggae backing track or music with improvised rhythmic speech

examples.text: she sang, rapped, and toasted, with a voice that was often tart and sassy
packed nightclubs feature DJs toasting over dub tracks
his toasting was a highlight of the set

shortDefinitions: (of DJ) accompany reggae backing track or music with improvised rhythmic speech
